title: A Teacher's Hope: Being Remembered
author: David A. Grenardo
content_summary: Teacher reflects on hope that students will remember not just lessons but the act of being taught with care and intention.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set

title: ardent
author: Amanda Bustos

analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Amanda Bustos appears multiple times

author: Alex Z. Salinas
content_summary: Reflection on past relationship, choices made, regret and memory intertwined like mountain smoke.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Alex Z. Salinas is most frequent author (9 poems total) - San Antonio-centric, mestizo identity, bilingual

title: Mriga
author: Sam Griffith
content_summary: Mythological conflict embedded in landscape and history, nature as site of eternal opposition.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set

title: Salt

analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Salinas poem #2

title: She told me that she too had a garden
author: E. Scott Alighieri
content_summary: Garden as metaphor for resistance, nature growing in urban space, survival through cultivation.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set

title: Red, White, and Blue

analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Amanda Bustos poem #2

title: Me As A Cog

analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; John Grey has 2+ poems

title: Everything At Once
author: John Grey
content_summary: Simultaneous experience of birth and death, language inadequate to express overwhelming feeling.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; John Grey poem #2

title: Trans Mom
author: Sara Eddy
content_summary: Mother accepting trans child, apologizing for past mistakes, expressing unconditional love through transformation.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Important LGBTQ+ representation

title: Pill Bugs
author: Sarai Argüelles
content_summary: Observing pill bugs, finding connection between nature's small creatures and personal growth, belonging.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set

title: Sixteen
author: Brandice Askin
content_summary: Queer teenage desire, coming of age, fire as metaphor for consuming first love and transformation.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; LGBTQ+ content

title: all the nameless saints
author: John Sweet
content_summary: Suffering of unnamed poor, cruelty of poverty, death without recognition or sainthood.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Very dark content

title: Binding
author: Jennifer R. Lloyd
content_summary: Seduction through books and literature, courtship as binding, playful eroticism in reading together.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Jennifer R. Lloyd poem #2

title: Don't Wake Me Up, Just Yet
author: Mike James
content_summary: Dream state blurring with digital reality, loneliness beneath playful surface, technology mediating intimacy.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set

title: Feeding the Fish
author: Rebecca Schumejda
content_summary: Visiting incarcerated family member, guilt over distance, survival amid neglect and confinement.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set

title: Firepool
author: Alex Z. Salinas
content_summary: Writing as calling, artistic commitment requiring risk, creative fire as pool to dive into.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Salinas poem #3

title: Kid Brother Dropout
author: Kevin Ridgeway
content_summary: Younger sibling living in shadow, family comparison, rebellion as path to self-discovery.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set

title: Mixed Feelings
author: Alex Z. Salinas
content_summary: Mestizo identity, complexity of mixed heritage, pride and defiance in face of 'what are you' questions.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Salinas poem #4 - identity theme

title: Morning Drive, March 2019
author: Alex Z. Salinas
content_summary: Daily commute in San Antonio, frustration with routine, dark humor, yearning for escape.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Salinas poem #5 - San Antonio-specific

title: My Father
author: Sandeep Kumar Mishra
content_summary: Estranged from father, unresolved past, confusion and sorrow over distance that cannot be bridged.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Mishra has 2+ poems

title: Oil or Men
author: David M. Taylor
content_summary: Interracial relationship, racist violence, domestic abuse, anger at systemic brutality.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Heavy content - violence and abuse

title: Over a Far City a Rainbow
author: Emma Lee
content_summary: Escaping abusive parent, finding independence and self, hope symbolized by distant rainbow.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set

title: Sanctuary
author: James H. Duncan
content_summary: Finding sanctuary in urban night, solitude as refuge, place holding memory and peace.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set

title: Shark Soup
author: Alex Z. Salinas
content_summary: Love as predation, fear intertwined with intimacy, vulnerability in dangerous desire.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Salinas poem #6 - dark love metaphors

title: Sir Bob
author: Alex Z. Salinas
content_summary: Satirical take on Bob Woodward, Watergate, journalism, and political power in American history.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Salinas poem #7 - political satire

title: Sister Cities
author: Abigael Leigh
content_summary: Kumamoto and San Antonio as sister cities, shared trauma of violence, strange tenderness in connection.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; San Antonio-specific

title: Sutherland Springs, 2017
author: Luke Neftali Villafranca
content_summary: Church massacre in Sutherland Springs Texas, gun violence, desecration of sacred space, American brutality.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Texas-specific, dated historical event

title: The Great Thing About Being Sometimes Hispanic
author: Alex Z. Salinas
content_summary: Not fitting fully in either world, sometimes Hispanic, passing privilege, never belonging completely.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Salinas poem #8 - major identity piece

title: TV Religion
author: Alex Z. Salinas
content_summary: Televised religion, questioning authenticity, sacred versus profane, media as spectacle.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Salinas poem #9 - critical of religious spectacle

title: Ode to the DMV
author: Jenine Baines
content_summary: DMV as symbol of bureaucratic frustration, daily absurdity, aging person's impatience with systems.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Dark humor

title: Coffins
author: Peycho Kanev
content_summary: Death as equalizer, coffins for all, dark humor about mortality and what we all share.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Peycho Kanev has 5 poems total

title: Dry
author: Jamie L. Smith
content_summary: Redemption through love after surviving mistakes, fire imagery, hard-won joy and liberation.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set

title: Get On Your Knees
author: Luis Cuauhtémoc Berriozábal
content_summary: Warning about mortality, consequences, damnation, defiant tone despite dark subject.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set

title: June 25th
author: Rudy Martinez
content_summary: Border deaths, prayer for migrants, witnessing tragedy, rage at injustice and loss.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Dated event, border politics

title: My Gallery
author: Sandeep Kumar Mishra
content_summary: Gallery of mental illness, depression, enduring pain, despair and darkness.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Mishra poem #2 - very dark

title: Neptune's Son
author: Daniel Edward Moore
content_summary: Childhood through mythological lens, transformation through wounding, nature and water imagery.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set

title: Okabe
author: William Doreski
content_summary: Immersion in art, traveling to foreign place (Japan), contemplating absence and presence.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set

title: Orange Shade
author: Brian Chander Wiora
content_summary: Intimate morning moment, love suspended in orange light, tender and dreamlike.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set

title: postmemory
author: Alicja Kusiak-Brownstein
content_summary: Inherited memory and trauma, ancestral experience passed down, haunting connection to place.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set

title: Provenance: Who Owns the Bathwater?
author: Christy Sheffield Sanford
content_summary: Frida Kahlo's bathwater, art market commodifying pain, questioning value and ownership.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; Ekphrastic - about Frida Kahlo

title: Pumping Gas
author: Jesse Breite
content_summary: Encountering homelessness while pumping gas, class guilt, shame, uncomfortable self-awareness.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set

title: Reunion
author: Steve Deutsch
content_summary: Reunion with dead friends, aging and stagnation, ghosts of past haunting present.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set

title: Silicon
author: Andrew Hamilton
content_summary: Queer love lost across rural/urban divide, Silicon Valley metaphor, technology creating distance.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set; LGBTQ+ content

title: The Kiss
author: Gary Metras
content_summary: Family ritual kissing, adolescent desire, first kiss fantasies observed with knowing wisdom.
analysis_notes: From original 47-poem analysis set - END OF INITIAL 47

title: The Truth About Bubbles
author: Charlie Brice
content_summary: Celebrates mathematician Karen Uhlenbeck's Abel Prize work on bubbles, exploring their ubiquity from dish soap to black holes. Wonders if we all live in bubbles of good intentions that will eventually burst into ether.
analysis_notes: New subcategory: Art & Science under Art & Creation theme

title: There Are Times of Silence
author: Ace Boggess
content_summary: About inability to quiet the mind's constant chatter - anxiety, self-talk, songs stuck in head. Speaker's brain described as dusty fan that won't stop, full of conversations that never happen and thoughts about failure.
analysis_notes: Expands Mental Illness & Depression to include Anxiety; introduces Anxious/Restless mood

title: Under This
author: Peycho Kanev
content_summary: Visceral imagery of diving into someone's skin, blood, sea trying to reach their heart. About drowning in love but taking years to realize it, with violent intimacy.
analysis_notes: Peycho Kanev poem #2 of 5 total; very short, intense

title: Upon Rails of Distractions
author: Diane Gonzales Bertrand
content_summary: Three-part poem about railroad crossing stops, contrasting modern distraction (phones, errands) with past generations who used train stops to connect with children. Speaker reads poetry with partner while waiting.
analysis_notes: New subcategory: Technology & Distraction under Technology & Modern Life

title: White With a Little Shade
author: Joel Fry
content_summary: Mysterious white girl with black hair walks ahead in fog like a reflection. References jazz, Creole culture, shared souls, voices dark as molasses - sensual and surreal imagery about connection and identity.
analysis_notes: Introduces Mysterious mood (could overlap with Mythic/Dreamlike)

title: Women's Hair
author: Larry Smith
content_summary: Sensual catalog poem describing women's hair through metaphors - smoke, threads, french curves, silk. Celebrates beauty and physical appreciation.
analysis_notes: Larry Smith poem #1 of 5 total; introduces Beauty & Appreciation theme; uses Grateful mood for appreciative tone

title: Banff
author: Joyce Schmid
content_summary: Jarring shift from Rocky Mountains (Banff, Lake Moraine) back to ordinary life - speed of modern travel makes beauty disappear instantly. Meditation on how those places still exist even when we can't see them.
analysis_notes: New theme: Travel & Distance; could also introduce Awed mood but kept to existing taxonomy

title: Dog Down
author: DA Borer
content_summary: Elegy for family dog Nai'a (German Shepherd) who died of cancer. Speaker digs grave while dog watches, describes euthanasia, morning after trying to read poetry but unable to find comfort.
analysis_notes: New theme: Pets & Companionship

title: Flight to Managua
author: Neysa King
content_summary: Giving money for plane ticket to someone named Enrique at Short Stop restaurant. Speaker regrets not letting him make hamburger so they could talk, imagines his new life in Nicaragua.
analysis_notes: New theme: Compassion & Kindness; uses existing Regretful mood

title: How to Swim with Dolphins
author: Jennifer Hill
content_summary: Sardonic piece about bucket lists and swimming with captive dolphins - absurdity of manufactured experiences. Warns against it because it's bad for dolphins and makes you question life. Ends with holding baby in pool who swims like dolphin - real, unexpected wonder.
analysis_notes: New theme: Capitalism & Consumption; mood shifts from satirical to tender at end

title: If someone says Catalina
author: Margot Kahn
content_summary: Memory of one-night stand with cello-playing boy who died of cancer. Sensual descriptions of intimacy, speaker preserving his memory so his mother knows that night is accounted for - about fleeting connection and bearing witness.
analysis_notes: Beautiful elegy for brief connection

title: Lake Tahoe
author: Kimber Annie
content_summary: Prose poem about growing up in Reno ('Biggest Little City in the World'). Celebrates contradictions of home - prostitutes and preachers, casinos and churches, heat and cold - nostalgic for place that welcomed contradictions without judgment.
analysis_notes: New subcategory: Class & Contrast (coexistence of wealth/poverty, sin/virtue); uses Celebratory mood

title: Last Walk of the Guard Dog
author: DA Borer
content_summary: Companion piece to 'Dog Down' - told from dying dog Nai'a's perspective. Dog dreams of hunting, recalls killing squirrels, asks for one more walk despite cancer pain - about dignity, wildness, and accepting death.
analysis_notes: Companion to poem #058; new subcategory: Nature & Wildness

title: Light Spectrum
author: Carter Vance
content_summary: Abstract, imagistic poem about time, memory, capitalism reducing wonder to figures. References 'mystic chord memory,' galactic time, being tossed to wolves - dense experimental language about rejecting commodification of experience.
analysis_notes: Experimental form; could use Abstract/Experimental mood but kept within existing taxonomy

title: Lines
author: Susan Niz
content_summary: Juxtaposes Texas daughters swimming in limestone pools with border-crossing daughters entering desert and dying. Lists borders: water/rock, war/peace, journey/cage, tyranny/freedom - powerful political poem about immigration and child deaths.
analysis_notes: Devastating immigration poem; uses Anguished mood

title: OCD
author: Joshua Lindenbaum
content_summary: Dictionary-style definition poem about OCD versus people who use 'OCD' casually to describe quirks. Details compulsive checking, intrusive thoughts, fear, treatment - critiques misuse of clinical term.
analysis_notes: New theme: Language & Misunderstanding; important mental health representation

title: Passing Time
author: Margaret Cantú-Sánchez
content_summary: About poor boy who walks to school an hour early because he has no clock at home and can't tell time. Details his morning ritual, journey, waiting outside school - about poverty, education, dignity.
analysis_notes: New theme: Education & Access; uses Dignified mood (related to Proud)

title: Que No Puedo Entregar
author: Brittany Leitner
content_summary: About being told she can't write whole book about being Mexican. Wrestling with Mexican identity, white-passing privilege, family, blood - references El Chico del Apartamento 512 song, mariachi band on shoulder, about authenticity and belonging.
analysis_notes: Identity and writing theme; similar concerns to Salinas poems

title: Sand Dollar
author: John Patrick Robbins
content_summary: Stark poem about lost love - couple's trips to ocean, photographing lighthouses. She moved on, he remains 'frozen to bleed stories.' She loved ocean and old lighthouses but never loved him.
analysis_notes: Short, powerful; writing as bleeding metaphor

title: Sitting
author: David Rosenheim
content_summary: About meditation practice - trying to quiet monkey mind, breath work, dealing with intrusive thoughts (money worry, career anxiety, neighbor's skinhead). The struggle and occasional moments of peace in modern meditation.
analysis_notes: New theme: Meditation & Mindfulness; captures modern meditation struggles

title: Song for Daniel
author: Luis Cuauhtémoc Berriozábal
content_summary: Elegy for cult musician Daniel Johnston. References his songs, hopes he meets Cobain in heaven, imagines a star for him in Austin - simple, direct tribute.
analysis_notes: New subcategory: Music & Legacy under Art & Artists; Berriozábal poem #2

title: The Minotaur-Daughter
author: Emily Bilman
content_summary: Dense, mythological poem about mother as minotaur-daughter, children watching her play game with ghost of Nun-Mother. References Eden, satyrs, trinity - surreal imagery about maternal power, sexuality, family dynamics.
analysis_notes: New theme: Sexuality & Power; very experimental form

title: The Wandering Gamete's Hymn to a Public Park
author: Colin Dodds
content_summary: About male gaze, desire, and irresponsibility. Speaker watches women in park with lust, admits to imposing fantasies on them, self-aware about being 'no gentleman' but unapologetic. Ends with everyone's been wanton and it's worked out kind of.
analysis_notes: New subcategory: Desire & Male Gaze; problematic but self-aware speaker

title: Waiting for the Coming Storm
author: David Prather
content_summary: About family members' bodily warnings of weather and change - grandmother's needles in hands, sister's knees, mother's teeth, father's heart, speaker's spine. Grandmother's folk wisdom about rain crows, turning back to wind, not looking at thunder monsters.
analysis_notes: New theme: Folklore & Wisdom; introduces Foreboding/Ominous mood

title: West Side Wonders
author: Jennifer R. Lloyd
content_summary: Catalog poem celebrating San Antonio's West Side - taco vendors, slow drivers, stray dogs, waitresses, pecan trees, first-gen college students. Gratitude for everyday working-class life, ends with seeing wonders like these the world over.
analysis_notes: Jennifer R. Lloyd poem #4; San Antonio-specific; new theme: Gratitude & Appreciation

title: Woman Posing
author: Jack Kristiansen
content_summary: Ekphrastic poem after Jan Gossaert portrait. Woman reflects on long marriage - lost children, surviving daughters, husband's hands. Says love is silly word, marriage was risky bargain that earned durable content through years of shared and unshared cares.
analysis_notes: New subcategory: Marriage & Endurance; ekphrastic; stoic tone

author: RC deWinter
content_summary: Explicitly erotic poem about insomnia and sexual desire. Speaker can't sleep, thinking about lover's touch. Very direct sexual language about masturbation, payback for partner's teasing, twist in wind of desire.
analysis_notes: RC deWinter poem #1 of 7 total; explicitly sexual content

title: 13 Ways of Looking at My Second Mother
author: Mary Rohrer-Dann
content_summary: After Wallace Stevens. About stepmother immigrant from Germany who defied her father, cut braids, left mother, came to America, became widow, remarried speaker's widowed father. Details her strength, bitterness, contradictions, wanting to go home.
analysis_notes: New subcategory: Motherhood & Sacrifice; after Wallace Stevens form

title: A Long Way from Underground
author: Stephen Roger Powers
content_summary: Tropical storm uproots tree, reveals skeleton wrapped in roots. Brief, stark - bones crave air and light of solved mysteries. About hidden deaths, nature revealing secrets.
analysis_notes: Stephen Roger Powers poem #1 of 2; new subcategory: Death & Mystery; new theme: Secrets & Truth

title: Audrey in Confession
author: Patrick T. Reardon
content_summary: Woman confessing infertility as sin. Uses Catholic language - transubstantiation, womb as stain and transgression. Ends cryptically with dream the tall policeman. About religious guilt, infertility, female body as site of shame.
analysis_notes: New subcategories: Body & Infertility, Gender & Shame; heavy religious guilt theme

title: Bear Trap
author: Brian Rihlmann
content_summary: Friend told speaker he had mind like a bear trap. Years later, speaker realizes those jaws have grabbed dangerous things that did more damage than animal teeth. About memory, trauma, holding onto pain.
analysis_notes: Powerful metaphor for traumatic memory

title: Box
author: Stephen Roger Powers
content_summary: About words trapped in meanings. Grandmother secretly read Barbara Cartland romances while doing hard farm work. Mother threw books away after funeral. Speaker watches dog in pink sweaters, imagines grandmother in chiffon and pearls she always wanted.
analysis_notes: Stephen Roger Powers poem #2; new subcategory: Gender & Expectations

title: Boy with blanket
author: Nicolas Visconti
content_summary: Very short poem about child's blanket as shield against monsters. Protection, safety, light and darkness - about childhood fear and comfort objects.
analysis_notes: New theme: Protection & Safety; very brief poem

title: Communion of Saints
author: Patrick T. Reardon
content_summary: Long catalog poem listing communion of saints everywhere - DMV line, subway, Christmas tree, Vietnam memories, voting, suicide. Argues everyone is saint and sinner (Hitler, Manson born innocent too). Litany of humanity's contradictions about universal sanctity and guilt.
analysis_notes: Patrick T. Reardon poem #2; new theme: Good & Evil; expansive scope; uses catalog form

title: Finding Scars
author: Max Heinegg
content_summary: Short, elliptical poem about body scars from various sources - bicycle, knife, scissors, nails, mirror, door. Speaker won't explain - once said you can't unsee. About self-harm, accidents, violence, letting others discover damage on their own.
analysis_notes: New theme: Self-harm & Violence; very brief, elliptical; dark content

title: Grandma's Journal
author: Brian Rihlmann
content_summary: Finding grandmother's journal - she misses dead husband, worries about family, wants people to believe God is real. Speaker at park sees old woman with walker, wants to wave, smile, be noticed. About loneliness, faith, seeing elderly people.
analysis_notes: Brian Rihlmann poem #2; tenderness toward elderly

title: Heed The Warning
author: John Patrick Robbins
content_summary: Very short, bitter warning - sad old men were once promising young fools. Warns against chasing dreams, feeding ego, ending up in company of poets. Dark self-deprecation.
analysis_notes: John Patrick Robbins poem #2;very brief;darkly humorous self-deprecation

title: His Hands
author: Brother Tom Giardino, S.M.
content_summary: About father's aging hands - left-handed, butcher's hands, later holding son's hand without shame. Father's acceptance of aging, patience, gratitude. Ends with shared religious faith, father's wedding ring now worn by speaker. About father-son love, aging, faith, letting go.
analysis_notes: New subcategory: Father & Son; beautiful tribute to father; religious author

title: I'm Full of Ashes
author: Edward Vidaurre
content_summary: Driving to work, smoking cigarettes, watching ash form planets. Dead possum on road. Feeling cold, alone, full of ashes - haven't prayed. About addiction, isolation, mundane despair, morning commute as spiritual emptiness.
analysis_notes: Addiction and spiritual emptiness theme; bleak tone

title: Lobsters in a Restaurant Tank
author: Peter Bethanis
content_summary: Watching lobsters in restaurant tank while waiting for table. Imagines their former life in Maine, how they ended up trapped. Circumstance half of any life. Their name is called - who will be eaten? About fate, entrapment, mortality.
analysis_notes: New theme: Captivity & Freedom; philosophical meditation on fate

title: Such Sweet Thunder
author: Jean Colonomos
content_summary: Uses math metaphor (borrowing in subtraction) for parents' marriage - they borrowed from yesterday's fight to fuel today's argument. Speaker wonders if strife kept marriage alive. About toxic family dynamics witnessed by children.
analysis_notes: New subcategory: Mathematics as Metaphor under Art; clever structural device

title: The tree line distant and still
author: Nicolas Visconti
content_summary: Father teaching child to fly kite near Love Field airport. Kite lost in trees, father crying beside child. About letting go, childhood memory, loss, becoming less. Beautiful, elegiac.
analysis_notes: Nicolas Visconti poem #2; new theme: Letting Go; very moving

title: To All Dog Owners in the Neighborhood
author: Carolyn Martin
content_summary: Humorous complaint poem about neighborhood dogs barking. Speaker irritated but softens when seeing cute dog videos. Considers getting earplugs, maybe reincarnating as dog. Satirical but ultimately tender.
analysis_notes: Light humor with softening; neighborhood life

title: Unfathomable
author: Brigid Hannon
content_summary: Powerful political poem using anaphora - I never had an abortion but. Catalogs experiences with reproductive shame, judgment, control. Stands with women who made impossible choices. About bodily autonomy, shame, solidarity.
analysis_notes: New theme: Reproductive Rights; very political; uses anaphora effectively

title: War Stories
author: Mary Rohrer-Dann
content_summary: Three-part prose poem about mother's shifting stories of WWII sexual assault by Moroccan soldiers. Story changes each telling - was she 9 or 14, one soldier or many, did cousin take her place. About trauma's unreliable memory, bearing witness.
analysis_notes: Mary Rohrer-Dann poem #2; very heavy content; trauma and memory theme

title: Watching a Train Go By
author: Glover Davis
content_summary: About graffiti artist tagging boxcars - dreaming some huge incomprehensible words. Sees it as flawed public art, ritual, oracular fire. Appreciative of outsider creativity.
analysis_notes: Celebrates graffiti as art form; appreciative tone

title: Carvings
author: Peggy Hammond
content_summary: Childhood friendship, blood sisters carving initials in trees. Friend had lazy eye, mother insisted on surgeries. Friends became surgeons themselves carving trees. Friend later struggled with addiction. Wonders if carved trees still carry their names.
analysis_notes: Bodily autonomy theme; childhood friendship and survival

title: Dirty Looks
author: Tom C. Hunley
content_summary: Father's anger about judgment toward autistic neurodivergent son. Kicked out of church, birthday parties, baseball games - some parents just don't know how to discipline their kids. Speaker bites tongue, spits blood. About parenting disabled children, public shame, rage.
analysis_notes: New theme: Parenting & Disability; powerful disability advocacy; protective rage

title: Foot Race
author: Ryan McMasters
content_summary: Prose poem about entering new relationships with fear. What if there were no shoes in equation, what if attraction was barefoot? Argues against self-sabotage, trauma as plot device, waiting for disaster. Affirms worthiness of happiness.
analysis_notes: New subcategory: Love & Fear; affirming and hopeful despite trauma

title: Giving the Finger to Mr. Death
author: Larry Smith
content_summary: Driving past funeral, seeing man offering purple death flags. Speaker flips him off, curses get back you prick Mr. Death. Then stunned at own defiance. References Robert Frost - miles to go before I sleep. About mortality, aging, refusal to accept death.
analysis_notes: Larry Smith poem #2; dark humor, Frost reference

title: How Do You Know You Can Do Better?
author: Ace Boggess
content_summary: Self-deprecating catalog of failures - out of breath, stub shins, debt, forsaken by cops, can't hear warnings. I'm a bull on the porcelain Earth. About incompetence, isolation, self-awareness of being a mess.
analysis_notes: Ace Boggess poem #2; darkly funny self-awareness

title: lipstick
author: RC deWinter
content_summary: Short poem about fall's beauty as deception - all the warmth implicit in those redgold leaves a lie. Fall as serpent's smile before winter's deadly kiss. Nature as betrayal.
analysis_notes: RC deWinter poem #2; very short, cynical view of nature

title: Other Little Brother
author: Tom C. Hunley
content_summary: About 11-year-old son who talks constantly - political insights, Bible questions, city council testimony, award-winning poetry. Speaker worries son will need to advocate for autistic brother when parents are gone, translate him to cops and judges. About sibling dynamics, disability, advocacy.
analysis_notes: Tom C. Hunley poem #2; new theme: Advocacy & Voice; companion to other disability poems

title: Quarantine
author: DS Maolalai
content_summary: COVID poem. Drinking tea, watching half-hearted quarantine from window. River imagery mixed with breakfast metaphors (burned bacon in fat). Sparse, observational - about isolation, pandemic, everyday surrealism.
analysis_notes: New theme: Pandemic & Isolation; sparse COVID documentation

title: Reliquary
author: Stephanie Garon
content_summary: Abstract, imagistic poem about separation and memory. Urban imagery (brick canyons, drain pipes), religious imagery (saint's hair in reliquary). I squinted past yellowed glass but could not reach you. About distance, inability to connect, memory as relic.
analysis_notes: Abstract, experimental; religious imagery for secular loss

title: Special
author: Tom C. Hunley
content_summary: About wanting autistic son to have savant abilities like Rain Man. Envies student with Asperger's who memorized calendars. Son struggles with speech (bottom 1 percentile) but can read clothing tags from across room, remember yearbook pages. Well that is fuckin' poetic don't you think?
analysis_notes: Tom C. Hunley poem #3; new subcategory: Hidden Abilities; complex parental emotions

title: The Chinwagger's Complaint
author: Carolyn Martin
content_summary: Playful complaint using obscure words (fopdoodles, snallygaster, snorllygosters, jackalopes, klazomaniacs). About people who use too many words, can't define vocabulary they pretend to know. Satirical, virtuosic wordplay.
analysis_notes: Carolyn Martin poem #2; virtuosic wordplay, satirical

title: The Coconut Palms Remember
author: Melissa Andrés
content_summary: Grandfather's coconut palms witnessed speaker's childhood - first steps, being dragged away from home. Trees hold proof of existence, memory of resistance. About displacement, trees as witnesses, childhood home.
analysis_notes: New subcategory: Trees as Witnesses under Nature theme

title: The Falls
author: Larry Smith
content_summary: Directions to local swimming hole (Cross Creek). People wade into water like Jesus on the waters, strip down, laugh together - earth's sweet baptism. About community, nature, joy, sacred in ordinary.
analysis_notes: Larry Smith poem #3; secular baptism theme; joyful community

title: The Grass Is Never Greener
author: John Patrick Robbins
content_summary: Elegy for someone who locked the world away, slowly allowing yourself to die. Meditations on mortality, stories we pass on, fear of unknown. We are like coins tossed into fountain - wishes with good intention somehow getting lost in dark waters below.
analysis_notes: John Patrick Robbins poem #3; elegiac, philosophical

title: The Orchid That Looks Out Our Living Room Window
author: Anna Ter-Yegishyan
content_summary: Experimental poem about orchid watching through window - watching neighbors, watching speaker. Uses fragmented language, spatial arrangement. Orchid and speaker mirror each other - both watching, both wilting. Ends watching hummingbird. About observation, parallel lives, domestic surveillance.
analysis_notes: New theme: Mirrors & Doubles; experimental form and spacing

title: The River
author: Larry Smith
content_summary: Teacher leading students into river for baptism not to God but to waters. Forever and forever you are one. Students become fish, water becomes them. Some laugh, some cry. About secular baptism, nature as sacred, communion with water.
analysis_notes: Larry Smith poem #4; secular baptism ritual; teaching poem

title: The Theory of Non-Relativity
author: Peycho Kanev
content_summary: Uses physics metaphor (massless particles, vacuum) for loneliness. You're the last dark matter from another outgoing night. Erotic plea - why don't you come with me, why don't you come in me. About loneliness, desire, forgiveness, forgetting death and birth.
analysis_notes: Peycho Kanev poem #3; physics metaphors for loneliness; erotic desperation

title: Two Covid-19 Poems
author: Alan Altimont
content_summary: Two poems - first about distance, zoom, resistance to each other, violence of protection. Second treats grief like COVID - wants to wash hands of it, scrub it off, but it won't come off. Grief you are still and always will be there. About pandemic isolation, grief as contagion.
analysis_notes: Two-poem set; grief as contagion metaphor; pandemic documentation

title: Warm Nectar
author: Robert Okaji
content_summary: Erotic nature poem - you are the apple I long to bite. Speaker wants to taste sunbeam hidden at your edges. Craves world but would settle for three minutes among your branches. About desire, nature, urgency, fleeting pleasure.
analysis_notes: Erotic nature imagery; urgent desire

title: You Will Not
author: David A. Grenardo
content_summary: Sonnet-style poem. First half: all negative you will nots from authority figures. Second half transformative - you will not commit same mistake twice, you will not lose faith, you will not ever give up the fight. Turns defeat into defiance. Inspirational teaching poem.
analysis_notes: David A. Grenardo poem #2; inspirational, teaching voice; transformative structure

title: A Lost Colleague
author: David A. Grenardo
content_summary: Elegy for colleague who died suddenly. Missed lunch, canceled plans, regrets. Questions if colleague knew how speaker felt, if he had regrets. I know they reside above and love will always reign. About sudden death, regret, religious comfort.
analysis_notes: David A. Grenardo poem #3; elegy with religious comfort

title: at the mouth of the tomb
author: RC deWinter
content_summary: Political apocalypse poem - fatigue is my raincoat it's been a wet spring. Flood of synthetic dancers politicians and heretics, counterfeit coins pour from hell's own slot machine. No medals awarded for speaking truth now. About political despair, 2020 moment, silencing.
analysis_notes: RC deWinter poem #3; political apocalypse; very dark

title: Bent
author: Gale Acuff
content_summary: 10-year-old boy in love with 25-year-old Sunday School teacher Miss Hooker. Asks her to marry him when he's old enough. She says ask again then. Boy negotiates, suggests her little sister could take up where you left off when Miss Hooker dies. Dark humor, inappropriate desire, child's logic.
analysis_notes: Dark humor; child's innocent but inappropriate desire; uncomfortable comedy

title: Blood Brothers Revisited
author: Harold Whit Williams
content_summary: Memory of cutting palms with friend Tom in bramble patch, blood oath. Now decades later, pasture is neighborhood, but speaker can still taste blackberries, hear meadowlarks, see scar, feel that faintest pulse of dear friend's summer heartbeat. About childhood ritual, time, enduring connection.
analysis_notes: Harold Whit Williams poem #4; beautiful memory poem; place transformation

title: Desire for Intimacy
author: Peycho Kanev
content_summary: Short, spare poem - it is getting late in the world. Moon and frozen lake sparkling. Black ravens in leafless space. I am here where are you I am here. Morning is getting closer and I'm waiting here surrounded by your absence. About loneliness, waiting, absence.
analysis_notes: Peycho Kanev poem #4; very sparse; desolate mood

title: Deus Ex
author: Max Heinegg
content_summary: About deaths that happen offstage, wrong timing. Actor hanging beneath fig tree (missing box), bridge crane crushing banker. Death's not as it was for Dionysus, offstage to keep ceremony sacred. God not in audience, only wanting to work. About arbitrary death, theatrical metaphor, no divine plan.
analysis_notes: Max Heinegg poem #2; theatrical metaphor for arbitrary death

title: Dim Memories
author: Peycho Kanev
content_summary: Long, surreal meditation on aging, time, waiting. I am here alone reaching out to sun. Every bone in me belongs to someone else who has yet to be born. Tomatoes like politician's face, boys like angels, old woman at door. Life as gold toilet paper roll. About solitude, time, mortality, surreal beauty.
analysis_notes: Peycho Kanev poem #5; long, surreal, accepting tone; strange beauty

title: i lied...i have the title
author: RC deWinter
content_summary: About pandemic time - days bleeding together, formless grey, circularity. When last train came through I missed it, I was in bathroom trying to zip up my sanity that shrank in the dryer. No words for what you're not feeling. Meta-commentary on writing itself.
analysis_notes: RC deWinter poem #4; pandemic breakdown; meta-poetry; dark humor

title: Inadequate Help
author: James Croal Jackson
content_summary: Pandemic poem - I counted twelve hundred drops of rain to cull drought in desert. Bodies dissipate into pixels on stuttering screen. Making purple cocktails. I know you are close when you made it but rain's still far away. About isolation, distance, inadequate connection.
analysis_notes: James Croal Jackson poem #5; pandemic distance; technology failing to connect

title: Libations
author: Christian Garduno
content_summary: Three-line poem - she dreams of me in matte, now that I've tasted blood, this wine is too thin. Vampire imagery, violence, desire. Sharp, minimal.
analysis_notes: Very brief; vampire imagery; cryptic and intense

title: Mingo Dreaming
author: Larry Smith
content_summary: Prose poem from perspective of city (Mingo) as living being. City watches over citizens like parent, worries about floods and fires, dreams of fish flying and trains climbing. Fears mill closing. All of us working through our dreams. About place as consciousness, community, industrial decline.
analysis_notes: Larry Smith poem #5; new theme: Place as Living Being; new theme: Industrial Decline; prose poem; personification of city

title: Mountaineering
author: RC deWinter
content_summary: Living atop smoldering volcano. Speaker too afraid to climb down (acrophobia). The devil you know you know. Ends praying for pyroclastic flow. About being trapped in dangerous situation, unable to leave, wishing for destruction. Mental health metaphor.
analysis_notes: RC deWinter poem #5; powerful mental health metaphor; trapped/paralyzed mood

title: Old-Time Music
author: Harold Whit Williams
content_summary: River as memory, grandfather on Birmingham radio, old Martin guitar. I have never heard this yet I can hear it, absorbed it like grit and sediment of tap water. Three chords river taught. I sing myself to edge of sea. About inherited music, ancestral memory, river as teacher.
analysis_notes: Harold Whit Williams poem #5; beautiful ancestral music theme; river as teacher

title: Some Emergency
author: DS Maolalai
content_summary: Minimal poem. Called into work Sunday morning. Streets look like christmas trees the second week of january. About emptiness, abandonment, post-holiday desolation.
analysis_notes: DS Maolalai poem #2; very minimal; post-holiday emptiness

title: Stilton Beach
author: Robert Halleck
content_summary: Six-line poem. Mist, cold house, empty days. Dog won't leave bed, knows woman won't return. Dog doesn't trust man who let her go. About loss, abandonment, animal grief.
analysis_notes: Very brief; dog's perspective on loss; guilt theme

title: The Bee's Sting
author: Emily Bilman
content_summary: Ekphrastic poem after Dali's Dream Caused by the Flight of a Bee. Dense description of painting - pomegranate, fish, tiger, bayonet. About art, sexuality, violence, Dali's solar libido. Surrealist interpretation.
analysis_notes: Emily Bilman poem #2; ekphrastic; Dali interpretation; dense imagery

title: The Old Country
author: Harold Whit Williams
content_summary: Landing in Ireland. Rain like some shroud to be lifted, rain ancestral and singing of pity. Dreams of seagulls, stout, faces around corners. Welcome home perfect strangers. About return to ancestral homeland, belonging, inherited connection.
analysis_notes: Harold Whit Williams poem #6; Ireland return; ancestral belonging

title: Twenty-One Epigraphs for the Workaholic's Retirement
author: Carolyn Martin
content_summary: List poem about retirement from workaholism. Only disconnect. Do nothing and rest afterwards. Put all your goals in box and burn that box. Advice for slowing down, embracing nothing, finding peace. About work addiction, rest, mindfulness.
analysis_notes: Carolyn Martin poem #3; list form; hopeful retirement advice

title: Wave to the Moon
author: Rose Mary Boehm
content_summary: Climate apocalypse. Islands disappeared, coastal cities drowned. We dance, yes we sing songs all but forgotten. About returning to water, developing gills, extinction. Dark ecological prophecy.
analysis_notes: New theme: Climate Change & Apocalypse; apocalyptic mood; ecological disaster

title: When your ring became too large for your finger
author: Rose Mary Boehm
content_summary: Memories of brother - gender expectations (girls can't whistle), childhood kites, airport pickups. Now brother weighs 160 pounds (wasting away). You used to span sandwich paper over balsa wood wings of model planes which will never fly again. About illness, decline, childhood memories.
analysis_notes: Rose Mary Boehm poem #2; illness and decline; tender childhood memories

title: After Reading 'State of Relax' by Eileen Myles
author: Patrick T. Reardon
content_summary: Long, complex response to Eileen Myles. References Joan of Arc, Myles' presidential run, Zoe Leonard's I want a dyke for president, states as lovers, nakedness, childhood constraints, openly human. Dense, allusive, queer, political. About escape, identity, relaxation as death.
analysis_notes: Patrick T. Reardon poem #3; very dense, allusive; queer politics; intertextual

title: An Anorexic to the Dead Mother Who Made Writing Bible Verses an Act of Self-Loathing
author: Janet Reed
content_summary: Powerful poem about anorexia, religious abuse, maternal punishment. Forced to write Bible verses 500 times. I puked my prayers. I pinned my hungers in folds of flesh too thin to bite. Erasing you by erasing me. About eating disorder as resistance, body as battleground, religious trauma.
analysis_notes: New theme: Eating Disorders & Control; very powerful; religious trauma; body as battleground

title: Before Karen Carpenter Added Anorexia to the Lexicon
author: Janet Reed
content_summary: Karen Carpenter, eating disorders, 1970s. Sisters on LSD, mothers in girdles. We would not be spiceless nuts and sweet mints. Diet products, Gerber baby food for adults. Karen left us end-stopped bone thin, hungry. About cultural pressure, femininity, starvation as rebellion.
analysis_notes: Janet Reed poem #2; cultural analysis; Karen Carpenter; 1970s women's bodies

title: Buried Alive On the Old Chisholm Trail
author: Harold Whit Williams
content_summary: Existential poem. Something went wrong beside dry creek. Seeking shaggy buffalo vibe, hearing ghosts in stereo. Past is not your friend, future not your enemy. Hair and fingernails grow longer, tang of prairie upon my tongue. About time, place, mortality, prairie spirits.
analysis_notes: Harold Whit Williams poem #7; Texas/prairie spirits; eerie surrealism

title: EMILY AS SHE ASKS ME ONE MORE QUESTION ABOUT MY PARENTS’ DIVORCE
author: Darren C. Demaree
content_summary: About parents' divorce. I was an apple smashed into the lunch bag. They never should have happened I tell her, I never should have happened. About feeling like mistake, living in margin, lying to protect self.
analysis_notes: Painful divorce poem from child's perspective; feeling like mistake; wounded tone

title: From the Dock
author: Ash Slade
content_summary: Prose poem about fishing with dad. Muffled lips don't move, not a murmur as we sat in placidity. Quiet bonding, throwing fish back, lasting bond in that span. About father-child connection through silence, nature as communion.
analysis_notes: Beautiful quiet father-child bonding; nature as communion

title: He Would Take You
author: Abigael Leigh
content_summary: Disturbing poem about predatory professor. He would take smooth summer legs now littering hallways and break each heart-shaped pelvis, alternating thrusts with hot waves of disgust and desire. About sexual predation, academic power, entitled violence.
analysis_notes: Abigael Leigh poem #2; new theme: Sexual Predation; exposing academic predation; very dark content

title: Just What Is It That Makes Today's Homes So Different, So Appealing?
author: Kenneth Pobo
content_summary: Surreal domestic poem. Dinosaur in post office, two men discussing ottomans, divorce hovers over us like honeybee above clover. Having baby despite being two men. Title references Richard Hamilton collage. About gay marriage, domesticity, mundane tensions.
analysis_notes: New subcategory: Queer Domesticity; surreal domestic life; Richard Hamilton reference

title: Poach
author: Max Heinegg
content_summary: Abstract poem about poaching eggs. Sour grapes in whirlpool the albumen, this ghost's getting caught. Brief, cryptic, experimental - about cooking, capture, theft.
analysis_notes: Max Heinegg poem #3; very brief and experimental; cooking metaphor

title: Premonition
author: Anannya Uberoi
content_summary: About rain in Langtang Nepal. Before it rains in Langtang, rain dolls pucker their cotton lips. Rain becomes mushroom, hibiscus, strawflower. Promise of resurrection to maples and pines from tremors and losses from year before. About earthquake recovery, nature's resilience.
analysis_notes: Anannya Uberoi poem #1 of 2; Nepal setting; earthquake recovery theme; beautiful imagery

title: priestless
author: RC deWinter
content_summary: Erotic poem about longing for sex. Long long legs made for running and jumping and opening wide wider widest. Religious imagery - sacrament of man, altar of desire. But there is no priest there is no priest. About sexual desire, loneliness, absence of lover.
analysis_notes: RC deWinter poem #6; erotic with religious imagery; desperate longing

title: Remember How
author: Anannya Uberoi
content_summary: About mothers working in factories. Our mothers worked in soot furnaces late into nights. Blistered hands, curry cooking, tying hair, brass hoops. Their bangled hands still chalked with white carbon. About working-class mothers, immigrant labor, beauty in hardship.
analysis_notes: Anannya Uberoi poem #2; new theme: Working-Class Mothers; beautiful tribute to immigrant mothers

title: Resurrection
author: Alex Z. Salinas
content_summary: Dream of being Christ's ashes, then Chaucer's scrolls, then ranch ghost. Dreaming of pious Christian wives who'd someday under sherbet skies etch their likenesses in drying family tree. About reincarnation, Christian mythology, Western expansion, family.
analysis_notes: Alex Z. Salinas poem #10; surreal reincarnation dream; Texas/ranch setting

title: The Idea
author: Ryan Quinn Flanagan
content_summary: Short poem about prison. Not about being toughest, but to be most affirming in his beliefs. Birdman of Alcatraz studying birds in such a way that no one would ever want anything to do with him. About isolation as protection, belief as armor.
analysis_notes: Brief but wise; prison philosophy; Birdman of Alcatraz reference

title: The Lottery
author: Emily Bilman
content_summary: Prose poem about retired botanists planning garden trip. Wife buys lottery ticket, gets mugged. Husband reserved Taiwanese restaurant. She cries like inconsolable little girl who had broken her favourite porcelain tea set. About aging, loss, small tragedies.
analysis_notes: Emily Bilman poem #3; new theme: Small Tragedies; gentle sadness of aging

title: The Morning Street of Shanghai
author: Zhihui Zou
content_summary: Prose poem about Shanghai's old street markets. Youtiao, doujiang, craftsmen, artists. Old people in faded clothes, smiling. They see here, they see now. Steam rising even higher than tip of skyscrapers. About tradition versus modernity, presence, working-class joy.
analysis_notes: Shanghai setting; new subcategory: Working-Class Joy; tradition vs. modernity tension

title: Ugly
author: Maeve McKenna
content_summary: Address to Ugly personified. O Ugly returned from your temporary leave. Commands Ugly to destroy beauty standards, loot this heart, make insults lethal affection. Ugly where is my war, I am armed. About self-hatred, beauty standards, weaponizing ugliness.
analysis_notes: Militant tone; beauty standards resistance; weaponizing self-hatred

title: Willy Lott's Cottage
author: Sam McDonald
content_summary: Ekphrastic poem about Constable painting location (Flatford). I skimmed my eyes over algae to Flatford and breathed in Constable's lungs. Watching duck on pond, how I might discolour this moment in more than observation. About art, landscape, England, capturing time.
analysis_notes: Ekphrastic; Constable painting location; England setting

title: at fault
author: RC deWinter
content_summary: Love as legal proceeding. Navigating by the heart is tricky business akin to being privateer. In court of love judgment is not only swift but final. No point in moving for mistrial. About love's permanence, judgment, no appeal.
analysis_notes: RC deWinter poem #7; legal metaphor for love; resigned philosophical tone

title: Blueberry Picking, 1972
author: Fredric Hildebrand
content_summary: Memory of blueberry picking with grandmother's Southern drawl, jam-making plans. Years later, alcoholism, divorce, suicide, and still the sweet ripe indigo taste. About memory's persistence despite tragedy, childhood innocence preserved.
analysis_notes: Beautiful bittersweet memory; tragedy contrasted with preserved innocence

title: cho bà nội (for my grandmother)
author: Julia Vu
content_summary: Vietnamese grandmother. Physics reference (energy neither created nor destroyed). Grandmother gossiping in restaurant, shuffling in slippers, hospital gown. When I listen to wind I can still hear symphonies of thousand years playing her to sleep. About death, energy, ancestral continuity.
analysis_notes: Vietnamese heritage; physics metaphor for death; beautiful ancestral continuity

title: December Song
author: Lisa Keeton
content_summary: Two-part poem. Actress in macabre rodeo/zombie play, cast party leads to pregnancy. Sister's body resting one mile from here. Compares self to Mary - life is given to me that allows my life's beginning. About unplanned pregnancy, sister's death, divine intervention, finding purpose.
analysis_notes: Complex layered narrative; religious metaphor; transformative moment

title: Deliverance at the Depot: An Introduction
author: Christopher Stolle
content_summary: Men arriving by train - appear to be Black men arriving at segregated depot. White laborers watching. Men tower over those down the road, grabbing luggage, their backs stiffening, their hands tightening. Unfair welcome to the cradle. About Great Migration, segregation, arrival, tension.
analysis_notes: Historical Great Migration; segregation tension; observant witness stance

title: EMILY AS FIVE PAGES OF TEXT IN ONE LOOK
author: Darren C. Demaree
content_summary: Short Emily poem. Lake Champlain, wanting to leave Ohio. If I had been a storm I would have given my winds to her eyes. About desire to escape, inadequacy, love.
analysis_notes: Darren C. Demaree poem #2; Emily series continues; Ohio setting

title: ER Visit
author: Jen Ashburn
content_summary: Surreal medical poem. X-rays reveal fish scales cemented to hipbones, zinc coating on ribs, black cherries of my medulla oblongata. Church bells of my youth ridicule me still. About body as strange object, trauma embedded physically.
analysis_notes: Surreal body imagery; trauma as physical manifestation; medical setting

title: Ghost Drafting
author: Joshua Bridgwater Hamilton
content_summary: Cleaning house to starve ghosts. Remembrance as negative renovation. Stripping rooms into corridors. We please the living - stuff them with electricity, air conditioning. The wraiths trail ever on thinner filament. About memory, ghosts, modern life, fading past.
analysis_notes: Joshua Bridgwater Hamilton poem #7; ghost metaphor for memory; modernity vs. past

title: hanging
author: German Dario
content_summary: Urban childhood - stickball, hide and seek, first kiss. Fireflies in all windowed cells bloomed forest fire wave. Waiting for someone who never came. About childhood, urban life, disappointment, waiting.
analysis_notes: Urban childhood nostalgia; waiting theme; city-specific quality

title: Heat Mirage
author: Joshua Bridgwater Hamilton
content_summary: Texas heat, laundry, detergent, past cocaine use, pyrrhic freedoms. Composting - all my broken parts swallowed into cool dirty wholeness. About recovery, Texas, domestic labor as redemption, transformation through ordinary work.
analysis_notes: Joshua Bridgwater Hamilton poem #8; addiction recovery; domestic labor as healing; Texas setting

title: Human Geometry
author: Mendy Zibulnik
content_summary: Mathematical meditation on relationships. Two people as Euclidean points - do they define line extending to infinity or remain isolated points with infinite distance? Does returning to seeing reality blunt terror of either option? About connection, isolation, mathematics as metaphor.
analysis_notes: Mathematics metaphor for relationships; philosophical anxiety; geometry as framework

title: March 14th
author: Ann Pedone
content_summary: Sexual/romantic poem. Last night I had trouble sleeping. Body under his, everything whitened. This body is still mine, salted by the past. The sea has all but been drained of its water. About bodily autonomy, relationship, emptiness, possession.
analysis_notes: Body autonomy questions; sexual uncertainty; emptiness metaphor

title: Marlene Dietrich Played The Saw
author: D. B. Fishman
content_summary: About Marlene Dietrich playing musical saw for troops in WWII. German actress who refused Nazi Party, brought saw to Ardennes. Said it was decent thing to do. Detailed description of saw's sound - eerily haunting, unembodied unearthly mutation. About duty, art, resistance, strange beauty.
analysis_notes: Historical tribute; WWII resistance; musical saw as unusual instrument; admiring tone

title: Neighbors
author: Shana Ross
content_summary: Panic attack at night. Hears barred owl, then screams - satan weasels, fishers. Calls police, operator triangulates location: You've got good neighbors, you're fourth to ring in, so that's nice in case of murder. About panic, community, surveillance, trust. Air conditioning wanting to equalize imbalances.
analysis_notes: Panic attack narrative; dark humor about surveillance; community safety theme

title: New England Soil
author: Ash Slade
content_summary: Prose poem about suburban childhood. Parents planting roots, ice cream truck, mowing lawns, sipping cold brews. Years spent young. About American suburban life, childhood nostalgia, New England.
analysis_notes: Ash Slade poem #2; idealized suburban childhood; American Dream theme

title: Remains
author: Joshua Bridgwater Hamilton
content_summary: Boiling pasta, partner's face, bathroom products mingling - Aquafresh, Old Spice, Lancôme. Marriage as comprehension including weaknesses, failures, and preserves of love. Ends with maintenance, compassion, nurture. About long marriage, intimacy, shared space, acceptance.
analysis_notes: Joshua Bridgwater Hamilton poem #9; beautiful marriage poem; domestic intimacy; acceptance theme

title: Slate
author: Sean Winn
content_summary: Welsh slate quarries. Grey skies, grey mountains, grey stone. Miners splitting slate for roofs and floors. Mines are tough but tougher when closed. Material so imbued with history cannot be blank slate. About Welsh mining, economic decline, history embedded in material.
analysis_notes: Welsh setting; mining and industrial decline; history in material theme

title: State Worker Catches Himself in a Lie, Then Realizes Truth is Far More Interesting
author: Harold Whit Williams
content_summary: Sonnet - It seems I've always been praying sort, if prayer is weeping along with FM songs upon lonely road. Talking to setting suns, birds, waves. Just thank those family photos on shelf, just thank stuff of stars you call yourself. About secular prayer, gratitude, being alive.
analysis_notes: Harold Whit Williams poem #8; sonnet form; secular spirituality; beautiful gratitude

title: The Life-Tree
author: Emily Bilman
content_summary: Ekphrastic after Leonora Carrington. Can I survive the very light I created irradiating from godhead. Philosophers arguing about truth. Is truth enlightenment from within like crystal lamp lit on grief-veined night. About art, philosophy, light, truth, hybrid creatures.
analysis_notes: Emily Bilman poem #4; ekphrastic; Leonora Carrington; mystical philosophical tone

title: You Always Demand Rain, But Only Supply Ruin
author: Jake Sheff
content_summary: Long formal poem in rhymed stanzas. Feast and Famine sections. Love as hunger, abundance, starvation. She taught lesson no one wants to learn. Starvation is her lifeblood, I will fast until what's never too available. Complex, baroque, about love's extremes.
analysis_notes: Virtuosic formal poetry; rhymed stanzas; love as hunger metaphor; ornate baroque style

title: Artist's Critique
author: Yolanda Wright
content_summary: Domestic violence as art. Heavy-handed strokes punctuate this piece. Artist's final touch—seal of Satan's kiss—fine pink mist—tragic masterpiece complete. Damn the muse who sent Artist my way, to hell with artist who killed me today. About abuse, murder, violence as art.
analysis_notes: Very dark; domestic violence murder; art metaphor for violence; victim's voice

title: Cloudy with a Chance of Atheism
author: Aanuoluwapo Adesina
content_summary: Haiku - Our sulky gods cried acid rain when prayers dried within earthen pots. About abandoned faith, environmental destruction, gods' absence.
analysis_notes: Haiku form; environmental and spiritual decay; cynical tone

title: Corona Seasons: haiku and senryu sequence (since 20202)
author: Dilys Wyndham Thomas
content_summary: Five haiku tracking pandemic seasons. Quarantine flowers—contactless delivery—memento mori. The months of absence, skin touched through haze of screens—hope bruised like blossom. About COVID seasons, isolation, masks, screens, repetition.
analysis_notes: Haiku sequence; pandemic documentation; seasonal progression; weary observation

title: Cosmic Trip
author: Trae Stewart
content_summary: Whimsical space travel poem. Surfing meteors, sauna by methane sea, poetry readings among stars, fashion shows, visiting marginalized Pluto, Elvis eating sandwiches. Until strings vibrate me home. About imagination, space, playfulness, Pluto as outsider.
analysis_notes: Trae Stewart poem #1 of 5 total; whimsical space fantasy; Pluto as outsider; joyful

title: Exhalation
author: David A. Goodrum
content_summary: Haiku - After crashing rain, sidewalks slippery with sighs evaporating. Brief, imagistic - about aftermath, release, ephemerality.
analysis_notes: Haiku; rain and emotion; evaporation as release; very brief

title: Fallen
author: Trae Stewart
content_summary: Haiku - fallen branches in virgin snow, abstract languages emerge. About nature, pattern, interpretation, language in chaos.
analysis_notes: Trae Stewart poem #2; haiku; nature as language; pattern-making; winter beauty

title: Hagia Sophia
author: Aida Bode
content_summary: About Hagia Sophia converted from church to mosque. You don't sing anymore, your bells don't ring on Sundays. Crescent holds no numbers. Grandmother weeping, six hundred years of unsang troparions. Ends asking what God would do if he had to give his only daughter. About religious conversion, cultural loss, gender, Byzantine history.
analysis_notes: Byzantine history; religious conversion (Christianity/Islam); gender critique (daughter vs. son); cultural loss; mournful anger

title: Hypothetical Star
author: Natalie Padilla Young
content_summary: Haiku - Speculated to, conjectured, has been or will become well-lit light. About potential, becoming, light - abstract, philosophical.
analysis_notes: Haiku; abstract philosophical; potential and becoming; light metaphor

title: Monsoon
author: Trae Stewart
content_summary: Haiku - monsoon at dusk, crickets become serenading gondoliers. Brief, imagistic - nature as Venice, transformation.
analysis_notes: Trae Stewart poem #3; haiku; playful transformation; nature as Venice

title: My Father, the Florist
author: Julián David Bañuelos
content_summary: Absent father poem using flower names. Rose forgotten and left like bluebonnet colored bruises you left behind. Texas flowers throughout. Tus labios whispering wisterias through me, you have always been here, a lilac in the air. About absent father, flowers as language, Texas, presence in absence.
analysis_notes: Beautiful flower language; Texas identity; bilingual (Spanish); absent father theme; presence in absence

title: My Parents Go In Swimming
author: John Grey
content_summary: Adult speaker watching lighthouse, remembering parents swimming 50 years ago. A man watches from headland of a boy, his beam is not near strong enough. About memory, loss, inadequate mourning, time.
analysis_notes: John Grey poem #3; lighthouse metaphor for inadequate mourning; time and memory

title: Nine Haikus
author: Rose Menyon Heflin
content_summary: Nine haiku on various subjects: motorcycles marking seasons, press censorship (pencils down now please, armed men politely order), closed hardware store, elephant rampage, Wisconsin ice fishing, prostitute's revenge, burning maples. Political, varied, observant.
analysis_notes: Haiku sequence; political themes including censorship; varied subjects; observant stance

title: NPV < 0
author: Sean Winn
content_summary: Suicide note using business language. I have forecasted my future happiness - net present value is less than zero, therefore project should be terminated. Cleaned house, wrote will, note for mailman: please call 9-1-1. About depression, suicide, corporate language for death.
analysis_notes: Sean Winn poem #2; very dark suicide note; business language for death; devastating matter-of-fact tone

title: On the Border
author: Gayle J Greenlea
content_summary: About Oscar and Valeria who drowned in Rio Grande 2019. Baby on father's back, face down in waters. Father swam back for mother, swept away. If you are brown and poor and desperate, do not come to America. About immigration, border deaths, racism, tragedy.
analysis_notes: Specific 2019 border death; Oscar and Valeria; devastating political poem; direct rage

title: On the Sea
author: Mark Burgh
content_summary: Abstract sea poem. Saltwater jerks and spits beneath all keels. Unwilling beast to carry ambitions across world. About migration, borders, dreams, sea as unwilling carrier. Cryptic, fragmented.
analysis_notes: Abstract migration poem; sea as unwilling carrier; cryptic fragmented style

title: State Worker Considers the Concept of Dualism, Then Shrugs It Off as Metaphysical Smoke and Mirrors
author: Harold Whit Williams
content_summary: Two sonnets from State Worker series. First about dualism, lightning bugs, lover's breath, Coltrane - science is on my side for sure but cannot close the deal. Second is prayer to God while drinking rum. About faith, doubt, embodiment, secular spirituality.
analysis_notes: Harold Whit Williams poem #9; State Worker series continues; two sonnets; faith/science tension; wry humor

title: The Believer
author: Mira Goldstein
content_summary: Haiku - Belief is to live, let God fill my closing eyes, belief is to die. About faith, death, paradox.
analysis_notes: Haiku; faith paradox; peaceful acceptance; life and death unified

title: Warming
author: Trae Stewart
content_summary: Haiku - warming, tundra thaws, nature's secrets revealed without intention. About climate change, permafrost, unintended consequences.
analysis_notes: Trae Stewart poem #4; haiku; climate change; ominous tone; unintended revelation

title: A Dove And I
author: Tim Krcmarik
content_summary: Paint can falls on hydrangeas, storm coming, speaker and dove watching someone in stockings studying their ass in mirror. One of us ultra-white as days before color, one of us gray as rains. Surreal, voyeuristic, about indecision, observation, desire.
analysis_notes: Tim Krcmarik poem #1 of 2; surreal voyeuristic moment; wry humor; desire and observation

title: Archeology
author: Sarette Danae
content_summary: We loved like ancient peoples. Love as fossil, embedded in strata, archived with shells and extinct creatures. Our fossilized love - the story of us and what once was. About love as artifact, geological time, legacy.
analysis_notes: Beautiful geological time metaphor; love as fossil; timeless contemplative quality

title: Beyond Death
author: Debasish Mishra
content_summary: Pain is seed which grows with time. Instructions for transcendence: burn bones, pour blood in sea, grind body to dust, strip mortality. Soul which can never be soiled is freed from bondage. You have to die to live. About spiritual transformation, death as rebirth, Hindu/Eastern philosophy.
analysis_notes: Eastern philosophy; Hindu/Buddhist concepts; mystical transformation; instructive tone; death as liberation

title: Dance this Sentence Now
author: Darren Black
content_summary: Haiku - Dance this sentence now, can't catch her, you're all noun twirling, she's all verb leading. Grammar as dance, language as movement - about pursuit, language, action versus object.
analysis_notes: Haiku; grammar as dance metaphor; playful philosophical; pursuit theme

title: House Party
author: Tim Krcmarik
content_summary: Crashing through champagne fountain, dragged out by Truth and Beauty, thrown in mud. My face is bleeding, my suit is ruined. But speaker sees beloved dancing in window, some divinity or other working your hips. About rejection, desire, persistence, divine beauty.
analysis_notes: Tim Krcmarik poem #2; dark comedy; rejection and desire; divine beauty amid humiliation

title: Letter from the Bardo
author: Kevin Roy
content_summary: Coffeehouse as bardo (Buddhist intermediate state). I dump the weather I carry in me. Students, dead parents, medications, marriage, trickster frogs and dissolving crabs. Seeking words in coffee shop - to hover and cohere, to shuffle and accrue what remains, and return a swarm. About in-between space, writing, suspension.
analysis_notes: Buddhist bardo concept; coffee shop as liminal space; teacher's life; writing process; weary contemplation

title: Low Tide
author: Darren Black
content_summary: Haiku - low tide, sea turns out its pockets, oysters snatched up by urchin birds. Sea as person with pockets, birds as street urchins. Brief, imagistic.
analysis_notes: Darren Black poem #2; haiku; sea as person; poverty metaphor; playful observation

title: Midnight Waltz
author: Saturn Browne
content_summary: To alcoholic mother. I can picture your gravestone in my mind so clearly, see that it has no name. Empty bottles, no love. The bullet that bites still burns and now the lamp has finally burnt out. About mother's alcoholism, death, lack of legacy, grief.
analysis_notes: Powerful mother-alcoholism poem; nameless gravestone; anguished grief and anger

title: Modern Religion
author: Sarette Danae
content_summary: List poem - I don't believe in ironing bed sheets, leaving shopping carts willy-nilly, saving wine for special occasions. No faith in stilettos or glass ceilings, saving face or original sin, guilty pleasures or hidden talents, tomorrow as hope or guarantee. About rejecting conventional beliefs, carpe diem philosophy.
analysis_notes: Sarette Danae poem #1 of 3; list form; defiant rejection of conventions; carpe diem

title: Mourning Dove
author: Sarette Danae
content_summary: Balcony, downtown apartment, bird calls. Mourning dove's call low like owl's hoot and hauntingly long. Imagining future reading this poem in different chair, at different home, with different view. Meta-poem about time, memory, future self reading present poem.
analysis_notes: Sarette Danae poem #2; meta-poetic; future self reading poem; time and change

title: Past Into Present
author: Ash Slade
content_summary: Prose poem - brain is stronghold caging acute points of drawn-out rolls of film. Memory as filmstrip, automated doors. One memory: riding in father's Mustang, autumn, corner store, potato chips. I savor the friendship we shared that afternoon, holding firm to its imprint. About memory, father, precious moments.
analysis_notes: Ash Slade poem #3; prose poem; memory as film metaphor; tender father moment

title: Prairie Dust
author: Katherine Hoerth
content_summary: Long meditation on Nebraska prairie. How to hold whole of her within your heart? Sandhill cranes, cottontails, spiderworts. Prairie's not woman after all, yet like your body, but site of awful beauty that's been plowed into submission. About prairie as body, colonization, beauty and violence, Nebraska.
analysis_notes: Katherine Hoerth poem #4; Nebraska prairie; prairie as body metaphor; colonization and violence; complex layered

title: River
author: Debasish Mishra
content_summary: River flows from my eyes every night. Dead father appears with halo, speaker touches his face, he evaporates. River stops with smiles, returns with tears. River resets limits of my world. About crying, dead father, grief, visitation dreams.
analysis_notes: Debasish Mishra poem #2; father visitation; tears as river; mystical grief; beautiful imagery

title: Same Page
author: Andi Myles
content_summary: Divorce poem - you got Shakespeare in divorce which feels unfair. Relationship as reading same pages. Once you know of Leda, Zeus never looks same, he forever carries bit of swan—which has always seemed to me a snake. About rape mythology, lost innocence, divorce, knowledge destroying beauty.
analysis_notes: Divorce poem; Leda and Zeus mythology; knowledge destroying innocence; bitter wisdom

title: Seventeen Years
author: Amanda Rosas
content_summary: Partner leaving after 17 years for Baja. You want to lose yourself, encounter yourself. Speaker transforms: I shock myself and become, expand to encompass wax residue of you. About long relationship ending, transformation after loss, self-discovery.
analysis_notes: Long relationship ending; transformation after loss; resilient self-discovery; becoming theme

title: Sitting Shiva
author: David Estringel
content_summary: Jewish mourning ritual for dead love. Love (this love) has left the room feet first. Call the shomer down the street, he really knows his Job. Rip collar, drape mirror, pawn wedding silver. About love as death, Jewish ritual, mourning relationship.
analysis_notes: David Estringel poem #6; Jewish mourning ritual for relationship; love as death; ritualistic bitter tone

title: Sunset/Flood
author: Joshua Bridgwater Hamilton
content_summary: Wolf at dusk, tobacco, tidal memory. In blind instinct a wolf pauses, swept by tidal memory, sea across land. Moon over forest. Spare, imagistic, natural - about transition, memory, animal instinct.
analysis_notes: Joshua Bridgwater Hamilton poem #10; spare imagistic; wolf and instinct; primal natural mood

title: The Bang
author: Therese Heinonen
content_summary: Long meditation on living bravely. Goldfish flushed down toilet surviving. Teacher shielding third graders from shooter. Beauty may be most real part of living. Universe collapsing into black hole, some small memory of beauty or love will sit somewhere in darkness and create enough energy to ignite bang once more. About courage, school shootings, beauty, Big Bang cosmology.
analysis_notes: New theme: School Shootings; cosmology and courage; beauty as eternal; defiant hope; urgent philosophical

title: The Grapefruit Tree
author: Katherine Hoerth
content_summary: Tree speaking after Texas freeze Feb 2021. All fruit fell, frozen. How can I go on? Impossible. Groves of trees weeping in silence in aftermath. Gulf breeze urges tree to try again. How can I do that God—to try again with such weight still heavy in my heartwood? About Texas freeze, climate disaster, grief, resilience, nature mourning.
analysis_notes: Katherine Hoerth poem #5; Texas freeze Feb 2021; tree's voice; climate disaster; nature mourning; questioning resilience

title: The News
author: Katherine Hoerth
content_summary: World ending but roly-polies, grackles, mockingbirds continue. I want to tell them that world is ending, wake them from their joy. Insects and birds rebuild, work, sing. When they learn our world is ending soon, roly-polies keep on moving earth—as they always have for centuries. About apocalypse, nature's persistence, resilience, pandemic/climate anxiety.
analysis_notes: Katherine Hoerth poem #6; apocalypse theme; nature persisting; tentative hope amid anxiety

author: James Croal Jackson
content_summary: In bog, taking photos, reference to Amy Winehouse. Yesterday after rent you went to post and mailed hundred letters to hundred lovers. There isn't enough space in this world to become expendable, not with seven point seven billion hungry humans all seeking something different. About love, expendability, population, seeking.
analysis_notes: James Croal Jackson poem #6; frenetic contemporary; population and love; multiple lovers theme

title: Amas Veritas
author: David Estringel
content_summary: Erotic/romantic - blue blush of midnight skin. Burn with me an hour, a minute, a second more. Casting away sinew and bone—the meat that binds us here. About passionate love, transcendence through sex, ephemeral connection. Latin title means You Love Truth.
analysis_notes: David Estringel poem #7; erotic passionate; Latin title; transcendence through love; mystical sensuality

title: Black is a Most Beautiful Color
author: Kurt Lovelace
content_summary: Race and color. Science says white is all colors, black is absence. But our skins are not science yet glisten with its presence. Bahamian fisherman, conch shell, gracious offering. Pale skin is not all colors but pink, canary, banana, mango. We are such beautiful colors of ourselves. About Blackness, race, childhood memory, science versus beauty.
analysis_notes: Celebration of Blackness; science vs. beauty; color and race; reverent celebratory tone; childhood memory

title: Chorus
author: Joshua Bridgwater Hamilton
content_summary: Trees as memory-keepers. Trees interrupt gestures, misplace memory's folded origami. Water hose left running. Oak, dogwood, maple with secrets. Green stellar force interrupts civic history, rooting its own memory in ours. About trees as witnesses, memory, nature interrupting human time.
analysis_notes: Joshua Bridgwater Hamilton poem #11; trees as witnesses theme; nature interrupting history; mysterious contemplative

title: Christmas Pecans
author: Joyce Kelley
content_summary: Grandmother sends perfect whole pecans. As child, speaker cracked them, relished it crumb by crumb. I wonder at powers that send such fragile beings forth into world quite whole, when they are best savored broken. About Christ child, pecans as miracle, brokenness as beauty.
analysis_notes: Joyce Kelley poem #2; new theme: Brokenness & Beauty; Christ child metaphor; tender philosophical

title: Commonplace Coffee on a Sunday in July, 2021
author: James Croal Jackson
content_summary: Coffee shop, masks encouraged, touching faces allowed again. We're allowed to now, to sip my rough mocha between gaps of my teeth under hanging honeybee lights, people all around me touching their own faces. Brief pandemic relief moment - about reopening, body autonomy returned, ordinary pleasure.
analysis_notes: James Croal Jackson poem #7; pandemic reopening; body autonomy returned; relief and tenderness; dated moment

title: Exegesis
author: Eugene Stevenson
content_summary: Aging, searching for identity. Let me sit here, figure out what I am about. How swiftly promise fades into once-was, leanness grows into largeness, mind into disrepair. Let me sit here awhile looking for my tools. About aging, mental decline, seeking definition, cosmic dust.
analysis_notes: Eugene Stevenson poem #2; aging and mental decline; searching for self; weary contemplation

title: Giant Asteroid, or What Would I Do Today if the World Ended Tomorrow?
author: Donna Castaneda
content_summary: What to do if world ends tomorrow. Gather son, eat soup, apologize to sisters, thank friends, water plants. Can I atone for my sins before tomorrow? List of treasures: breeze, cormorant, vinca flowers. About apocalypse, priorities, treasures, atonement.
analysis_notes: Apocalypse priorities; what matters at end; gratitude list; family reconciliation; urgent contemplation

title: Hibernation Sonnet
author: Alicia Hoffman
content_summary: Western New York winter versus California. Better that than California - sun there is flare blaring impending disaster. Darkness as closed book, time unspools. Loves copping out, canceling plans. O East Coast polar vortex, O Eden, cast me out, I'll beg back in. About depression, winter, darkness as comfort, avoiding California sun.
analysis_notes: Depression as hibernation; darkness preferred; NY vs CA; wry self-aware; sonnet form

title: Ideal user
author: Kunle Farawe
content_summary: About being created as data - you were created in your first image, a jpeg file. Exported as svg, machine learning watched you grow. Brain inside of you that makes you think, act and react like ideal user you imagine yourself to be. About AI, data identity, algorithms, constructed self.
analysis_notes: New theme: AI & Technology; data identity; dystopian tech critique; contemporary digital self

title: Indigo
author: David Estringel
content_summary: Long meditation on indigo/blue. Morning coffee, drip-dried epiphanies. Blue sky that bruises sky before its skin splits. Rain like napalm, smells like cuts and mud and shit. Depression as color. Today I feel indigo—Indigo King of the Blues. About depression, color, rain, longing, blues music.
analysis_notes: David Estringel poem #8; depression as color (indigo); blues music mood; sensory rich; long meditation

title: Intolerance: The Second Flood
author: Holly Shupp Salas
content_summary: Rain as racial division - rain falls from its sieve, separate but equal. Oil and water, oil and water denouncing apart, refusing together. God keeps His promise, we flood ourselves. About racism, segregation, flood as self-destruction, biblical promise.
analysis_notes: Racism as oil/water; segregation flood; biblical second flood; prophetic angry tone; self-destruction theme

title: Meteor Game
