author: M.E. Silverman
content_summary: Father creates baseball game with planets. Earth as grass circle, Mars as first base, Jupiter as second (bean bag), Neptune as pool. Quiz questions about space. Father sings Fly Me To The Moon. About father-child bond, imagination, space, play, education.
analysis_notes: M.E. Silverman poem #1 of 2; joyful father-child play; space and imagination; educational game

title: Peppered Moths Predict the Future
author: M.E. Silverman
content_summary: Industrial melanism - moths turned black from pollution. They bathed in sunshine, soaked in roses' halo glow, now camouflage themselves as chimney sweepers. Watch Mary Poppins, dream burnt skies. When drunk on nectar they tell fortunes that are bleak and predict only demise. About evolution, pollution, Industrial Revolution, doom, adaptation.
analysis_notes: M.E. Silverman poem #2; new theme: Evolution & Adaptation; industrial melanism; twisted whimsical doom; Mary Poppins reference

title: Reruns
author: James Croal Jackson
content_summary: May afternoon, homemade salad, carrying air conditioners. Using heat-gun and pliers I straighten my brain's antenna. Our argument becomes static on tube TV. About relationship argument, mental static, mundane domesticity, TV metaphor.
analysis_notes: James Croal Jackson poem #8; TV static metaphor for relationship; weary domesticity; contemporary conflict

title: Skin
author: Josiah Nelson
content_summary: October light, air packing itself. Dig Yukon potatoes, steam soup, look out window. Wonder if we wear each other for warmth. About autumn, intimacy, layers, wearing each other as protection.
analysis_notes: Josiah Nelson poem #1 of 2; beautiful intimacy; wearing each other for warmth; autumn setting; tender peaceful

title: Stones Into Prairie
author: Eugene Stevenson
content_summary: Contrast seaside (soft, warm, moon-pulled, womb-held) versus prairie (stretched, burned, seared, indifferent). When they chose to live hard-tack-land they sank like stones into prairie. About migration, choosing harsh land, sinking into earth.
analysis_notes: Eugene Stevenson poem #3; prairie as harsh indifferent; migration and choice; sinking metaphor; somber

title: The Marble Machine
author: Joyce Kelley
content_summary: Sonnet about heirloom toy. Father's mother watched uncle make it for abandoned child. Five generations have enjoyed this fun—each sing our joy until our path is done. About generational continuity, wooden toy, music, inheritance, joy across time.
analysis_notes: Joyce Kelley poem #3; new theme: Generational Continuity; sonnet form; five generations; joyful grateful; musical quality

title: Workshop of Wills
author: James B. Nicola
content_summary: Pro-bono will-drafting at MetLife. Tables laid out in roomy rows too plush for barracks but as graves might be arranged. Lawyers stay for catered lunch, more people coming. About death preparation, corporate setting, transactional mortality.
analysis_notes: New theme: Death & Bureaucracy; corporate death prep; wills as transaction; dark wry observation; graves metaphor

title: Wrinkle
author: Josiah Nelson
content_summary: Time through relationship wasn't sand but wind. It was wind brushing through leaves, wrinkle of air nicking crisp edge of your life against mine. For a moment we shared sky aloft and always about to fall. About ephemeral connection, time as wind not hourglass.
analysis_notes: Josiah Nelson poem #2; time as wind not sand; ephemeral love; beautiful tender wistful; temporary connection

title: (True) Love in an Elevator
author: Matthew Byrne
content_summary: Elevator malfunction, entire relationship in cramped quarters. We saw our kids off to college, watched our 401k ebb and flow. When our cancers metastasized we leapt hand in hand down shaft. About compressed time, entire life in elevator, choosing death together.
analysis_notes: Matthew Byrne poem #4; new theme: Compressed Time; entire life in elevator; surreal romantic; chosen death together; darkly romantic mood

title: A Rake's Progress
author: Bruce Robinson
content_summary: Brief poem. Sidewalk swept yesterday, today after rain peppered with vegetation. Rake sees its fluid utility. About impermanence, work's futility, nature returning, rake's perspective.
analysis_notes: Bruce Robinson poem #1 of 2; very brief; object perspective (rake); nature returning; philosophical acceptance

title: A Tacit Prayer
author: Natalie Wollenzien
content_summary: Prose poem. Shared laughter, picnic blankets, planning travels. Waking early to salute geese. Your mouths dry from speech and song, glow unfolds beneath pavement and you start to smile at nothing. About friendship, joy, geese ritual, simple pleasures, connection.
analysis_notes: Prose poem; friendship celebration; geese ritual; simple pleasures; joyful tender

title: Advice from the Mechanic
author: Bruce Robinson
content_summary: Two-line poem - You must have done something wrong. About blame, guilt, mechanics, authority, accusation.
analysis_notes: Bruce Robinson poem #2; extremely brief (two lines); accusatory tone; blame and guilt; minimalist

title: Because Your Crazy Uncle is Ten Memes Behind
author: Kyle Lee
content_summary: Long comic poem about uncle's outdated internet. AOL, CDs, 404 errors, instant messenger, fantasy MMOs, Alta Vista search disasters. You're going to be my kids' crazy uncle. About generational tech gap, family eccentricity, internet archaeology, affection.
analysis_notes: New theme: Internet Archaeology; generational tech gap; affectionate humor; family eccentricity

title: Cause 'bad things get better'
author: Tyson Wilson
content_summary: Refrain: bad things get Better. Clover keychain, makeup sex, sunken couch, carcinogenic rain. Washing away old prints so new ones might come. About toxic relationship, false hope, repetition, pollution.
analysis_notes: Tyson Wilson poem #1 of 2; cyclical toxic relationship; false hope refrain; dark resigned cyclical mood

title: Childhood Friends
author: Grayson McDaniel
content_summary: Friends once as brothers. But these pleasant outings would suddenly come to halt when your slipped race preferences brought me to halt. Oh dear brothers from another white mother, our ties unknot. About racism ending friendship, casual prejudice, loss, white friends.
analysis_notes: Racism destroying friendship; casual prejudice; white friends; brothers from another mother; sad resigned

title: Disinformation Campaign
author: Matthew Byrne
content_summary: Satirical about propaganda. They musn't know what we know. We need them to look themselves in eyes in our funhouse mirror, comfortable in someone else's skin, good to go without going anywhere. About misinformation, control, truth manipulation, conspiracy.
analysis_notes: Matthew Byrne poem #5; new theme: Disinformation & Propaganda; satirical dark cynical; funhouse mirror metaphor

title: End of The Year Junior High Classroom Address by The Teacher’s Assistant
author: Mark Parsons
content_summary: Long rant from teacher's assistant. Statistics about anger and violence. The worst you imagine in all worst-case scenarios never happens. Just take deep breath and tell them what they want to know. About honesty, violence, trauma, post-traumatic stress, truth versus honesty distinction.
analysis_notes: New theme: Honesty & Truth; teacher's trauma; post-traumatic stress; manic instructive rant; violence statistics

title: Ferretccine
author: Tyson Wilson
content_summary: Brief ode to ferrets as pasta. O Fur-Noodles, saucy bacchanalian spaghetti sautéing in box, bouncing on black beans. About ferrets, playfulness, pets as food metaphor.
analysis_notes: Tyson Wilson poem #2; whimsical pet ode; ferrets as pasta metaphor; playful joyful; brief

title: Little Death Livestock
author: Jane Rosenberg LaForge
content_summary: Boyfriend lied about friendly bull on grandfather's farm. No bull existed. Speaker was city/suburb girl, homesick, remembering children's book about friendly bull. I remember this bull like the other, as black and shiny on its flanks as sable. About lies, childhood nostalgia, believing myths, suburban origins.
analysis_notes: Jane Rosenberg LaForge poem #1 of 2; lies and believing myths; childhood book reference; city/suburban girl; wistful knowing

title: Nightly Visitors
author: Charles Blalock
content_summary: My dreams are like ghosts: they come and go as they please in river called sleep. Haunting with mistakes. When I find myself awake they cease to exist. Brief about dreams, guilt, sleep.
analysis_notes: Brief; dreams as ghosts; guilt and mistakes; haunting mood; sleep metaphor

title: Opposites Attract
author: E. Martin Pedersen
content_summary: E-man Electric Man Modern Superman goes electric. Questions about electricity - when current runs through wires is it moving? Reunion kiss with static shock. We synchronized our breathing, our heartbeats, we were both pregnant ready to give birth to new generation. About electricity, reunion, synchronization, transformation.
analysis_notes: E. Martin Pedersen poem #1 of 2; electricity metaphor; ecstatic reunion; synchronization; transformative pregnancy; electric mood

title: Party Animal
author: E. Martin Pedersen
content_summary: There's always that one guy, odd man out, sitting back in corner, completely Nick Cave. Half deaf, doesn't work room. Yesterday he heard fine. About social anxiety, deafness, outsider at parties, isolation.
analysis_notes: E. Martin Pedersen poem #2; social anxiety and deafness; party outsider; Nick Cave reference; sad isolated

title: Pleasure Principle
author: Lucas Jorgensen
content_summary: Fragmented philosophical meditation. Purpose of exercise is to prove red at deep enough depth looks blue. More people would rather be most miserable person than most pleasured pig. Washing dishes, imagining skin sloughing. When I look at my head on microscope platter I see two planets on course to collide or kiss - one I named pleasure, other pain. About philosophy, hedonism, dialectic, pleasure/pain binary.
analysis_notes: Fragmented philosophical; hedonism and utilitarianism; pleasure/pain dialectic; analytical fragmented mood

title: The Canadian Goose
author: Matthew Byrne
content_summary: Humorous rant against geese. Garbanzo bean brain bestially aware of its federal protection. Minefield of black snake firework shaped feces. You refuse to be spellbound by its versatility, ruthless adaptation, nor how goddamn cute its babies. About irrational hatred, Canadian geese, childhood fear.
analysis_notes: Matthew Byrne poem #6; humorous rant; irrational animal hatred; irritated playful; aggressive humor

title: The Potential in Architecture
author: Jane Rosenberg LaForge
content_summary: Ranch house built for hearing woman. Echoes travel. Mother complains voices dwindling, no TV before homework, no pets without approval. The neighbors will know everything at this rate. About house acoustics, family rules, hearing/deafness, suburban life.
analysis_notes: Jane Rosenberg LaForge poem #2; architecture and sound design; deafness/hearing theme; family privacy; tense observant

title: This is Your Poem, Rabbit
author: Carol Lee Saffioti-Hughes
content_summary: Finding dying rabbit. I never thought wildness in you would ever let me hold you but there we sat awhile, you in my lap. Speaker strokes rabbit, checks for breaks, sits in March wind. Your eyes opened as if to see if I was still there, mine closed as if shutting out world could make it go away or help you stay in it. About dying animal, tenderness, helplessness, witness.
analysis_notes: Beautiful animal death poem; tender witness; helplessness and care; gentle aching; addressed to rabbit

title: Tortillas
author: Lisa McGrew
content_summary: Grandmother making tortillas, speaking Spanish. Teenage speaker refuses to learn, ashamed of accent, teased at school. Called Weda (light-skinned), coconut. I turned my back on what she had to teach me and left it all behind. Grandmother died when speaker was young. The burden of rejecting her I carry now as my cross. About assimilation, shame, language loss, regret, Mexican-American identity.
analysis_notes: Powerful assimilation shame poem; language loss and regret; grandmother relationship; Mexican-American identity; burden of rejection

title: What Little Remains of the Winter
author: Alessio Zanelli
content_summary: Looking at sky, tidying books, finding old photos. I haven't found what I was looking for. Looking ahead to next winter. Aware I can see at most three thousand stars among about four hundred billion more. About searching, seasons, time's sequence, cosmic scale.
analysis_notes: Searching without finding; cosmic scale perspective; seasons sequence; peaceful contemplative; cosmic mood

title: BBQ
author: Mary Croy
content_summary: Cooking alphabet letters on BBQ. Shall we have smoked alphabet today? Can't beat g dipped in French Onion sauce. Letters on skewer, recognize phrase. About language as food, cooking words, playful concrete poetry.
analysis_notes: Concrete poetry; language as food metaphor; playful whimsical; experimental form; cooking words

title: Bedrock
author: Benjamin Harnett
content_summary: Old home built into bedrock. Basement chiseled with hammer and pick. Found pie safe, oil furnace, beams of bark-on fir. A fitting place to find handiwork of old lives' patching and ourselves. About foundation, geological time, building on stone, finding self in structure.
analysis_notes: Foundation and bedrock theme; geological deep time; building on stone; finding self in structure; grounded reverent

title: Black Wreaths (a winter's settling)
author: David Estringel
content_summary: Song/poem about old house, dead loved one. Refrain: Where you've gone I can't follow. House tells secrets, grows tired. But I know love can take me there. About haunted house, grief, waiting to die, love as bridge.
analysis_notes: David Estringel poem #9; song structure with refrain; haunted house grief; love as bridge to death; musical mournful

title: Cheers
author: Kenton K. Yee
content_summary: About TV show Cheers characters as bartenders. This one stirs up bubbles, that one splices and fries. Reference to Diane, Frasier. Brief, playful TV reference poem.
analysis_notes: TV nostalgia; Cheers reference; bartender characters; brief clever playful; pop culture
